slide.title: Routing
slide.p: Routing is the process of determining how to handle an incoming request. This can be done by explicit configuration, or "by convention".

All frameworks support routing by configuration. CodeIgniter can also handle routing by convention, with controllers expected to be found inside application/controllers without additional or specific configuration.

Routing is essential to a framework. Many frameworks were started by figuring out the routing first, and then by designing and building components to support the routing and the "controllers" that would be the result of "doing" the routing.

slide.title: Apache View of URIs
slide.p: Apache needs to know either what to return for a request (eg. the contents of a named file) or what object to execute in response to a request (eg. index.php).

tr.td: The file "stuff" in the document root
The "index.php" script in the document root
The "index.php" script in the document root
The "index.php" script in the document root

slide.p: If the file or object is not found, Apache returns a 404.

slide.title: CodeIgniter View of URIs
slide.p: CodeIgniter needs to know which controller to execute in response to a request (eg. Stuff.php).

tr.td: If the file "stuff" exists in the document root, Apache handles the request.
Invoke the "Stuff" controller. This assumes that query strings have been enabled.

slide.p: If the controller is not found, CodeIgniter returns a 404.

slide.title: SEO View of URIs
slide.p: Search engines need to know the "resource" to associate with a request
If the request returns a 404, the search engine will treat the content as unavailable.
